questions.question: I waited for them …………………….. they came.
……………………. men sow, so shall they reap.
questions.description: As is a conjunction like is a preposition. We need a conjunction to connect two clauses.

questions.question: I am as strong ……………………….. you are.
questions.description: To say that people or things are equal in a particular way, we use the structure as…as…

questions.question: He was …………………….. tired that he could barely stand.
questions.description: We cannot use a that-clause after very or too.

questions.question: It is certain …………………… he will be late.
questions.description: Noun clauses are often introduced by the conjunction that.

questions.question: ………………………. a large sum of money, he gave up speculation.
questions.description: He lost a large sum of money. He gave up gambling. We can combine them with the perfect participle 'having lost'.

questions.question: ……………………….. he will waste his time is certain.
questions.description: He will waste his time. That is certain. When we combine them we get: That he will waste his time is certain.

questions.question: ……………………….. he is short-tempered, I like him.
questions.description: Despite is a preposition however is a transitional adverb although is a conjunction. We need a conjunction to connect two clauses.

questions.question: Ask the guard …………………………. it is time for the train to start?
questions.description: Indirect yes/no questions can be introduced by if or whether.

questions.question: ……………………. I know all the facts, I cannot help you.
The votes on each side …………………… equal, the chairman gave his casting vote against the resolution.
questions.description:
When we split the sentence we get:
The votes on each side were equal. The chairman gave his casting vote against the resolution.
When we combine these two clauses into a simple sentence, we use the participle ‘being’.

questions.question: ……………………. tired, he stopped working.
questions.description: When we split clauses, we get: He felt tired He stopped working. We can combine them with the present participle 'feeling'.
